name: The Gig Economy and the Future of Work

chapters.name: What Is the Gig Economy?
topics: Why is the 'gig economy' surprisingly hard to define—and why do different definitions yield different size estimates?
What is platform work, and why do platforms claim to be marketplaces rather than employers?
How large is the gig economy really, and how many workers depend on it as primary income?
What is new about gig work compared to freelancing and contracting that have existed for centuries?
Why has the gig economy grown from both employer and worker perspectives?
What fundamental questions does the gig economy raise about what 'work' even means?

chapters.name: The Platform Business Model
topics: How do platforms position themselves as technology firms rather than employers—and what does this obscure?
Why do the economics of platform work heavily favor platforms over workers?
How has risk been transferred from companies to workers who earn nothing when there are no gigs?
What network effects create winner-take-all dynamics that reduce competition and worker options?
Why have platform companies like Uber been remarkably unprofitable despite extracting value from workers?
What happens to worker earnings when investors demand profits from loss-making platforms?

chapters.name: Employee vs. Contractor: The Classification Battle
topics: Why do billions of dollars—and the viability of the platform model—hang on the employee vs. contractor distinction?
What are the different legal tests—IRS, economic reality, ABC—and why do they yield different results?
How does the ABC test work, and why do gig workers typically fail at least prong B?
What did California's AB5 require, and how did gig companies respond with Proposition 22?
What hybrid category did Prop 22 create, and what are the limits of its benefits?
What rules is the Biden administration proposing, and why will the classification battle continue for years?

chapters.name: California's Prop 22 and the Corporate Playbook
topics: How did Uber, Lyft, DoorDash, and Instacart spend over $200 million on Prop 22—the most expensive ballot measure in California history?
How was the campaign carefully crafted to frame the issue as worker choice versus lost flexibility?
What do Prop 22's actual provisions provide—and how do they compare to genuine employment?
Why does Prop 22 require a seven-eighths supermajority to amend, making it virtually impossible to change?
How has Prop 22 created a playbook that companies are attempting to replicate in other states?
What are the long-term effects of benefits determined by corporate negotiation with voters?

chapters.name: Algorithmic Management: Your Boss Is an App
topics: How do algorithms in the gig economy assign work, set pay, evaluate performance, and terminate workers?
How do work assignment algorithms determine who gets jobs based on factors companies don't fully disclose?
What is dynamic pricing, and why does its opacity create anxiety and constant app-checking?
How do ratings systems create constant performance pressure without meaningful appeal?
What forms does surveillance take—GPS, driving patterns, delivery times—and how does it shape behavior?
What are the psychological costs of algorithmic management stripped of human connection?

chapters.name: Warehouse Work: Amazon and the New Factory
topics: What is it like to work in an Amazon fulfillment center where productivity is monitored with precision?
What does 'rate'—the speed target workers must meet—mean in practice for workers?
Why are Amazon warehouse injury rates roughly twice the industry average?
What does it mean that Amazon reportedly turns over its entire warehouse workforce within about three years?
How is automation advancing, and what is the long-term direction for human workers?
What did the Amazon Labor Union victory in Staten Island show about worker power—and what obstacles remain?

chapters.name: Remote Work: Liberation or Exploitation?
topics: What did the COVID-19 forced experiment in mass remote work reveal about productivity and worker preferences?
What genuine benefits does remote work offer for commute savings, flexibility, and accessibility?
How can remote work blur boundaries, create always-on availability, and increase isolation?
How has surveillance software followed workers home with keystroke tracking and screenshot monitoring?
Why is remote work not equally available—and how did the pandemic widen class divides?
How will hybrid arrangements be contested between workers who want flexibility and employers who want control?

chapters.name: AI and Automation: The Jobs Question
topics: How does AI differ from previous automation by replacing cognitive tasks and learning from data?
Why do predictions about AI's job impact vary wildly—from a quarter of jobs to minimal disruption?
Which jobs are most exposed to AI automation, and why do boundaries keep shifting?
What does history suggest about new jobs emerging—but also painful transitions that leave workers stranded?
What policy choices around training, social insurance, and regulation shape automation's effects?
How will society manage the transition to protect those affected by AI-driven change?

chapters.name: The Hollowing Out of the Middle
topics: What is job polarization—growth at the top and bottom, decline in the middle—and what caused it?
How did computers and automation replace the routine tasks that provided middle-wage employment?
How did globalization reinforce automation's effects by moving manufacturing jobs overseas?
What happened to the path from high school to middle-class life that manufacturing once provided?
Why is 'more education' an insufficient prescription for addressing polarization?
What structural changes—minimum wages, unions, public investment—could address polarization as a policy outcome?

chapters.name: Portable Benefits and the New Social Contract
topics: How was the American safety net built around stable, full-time employment—and why is that assumption crumbling?
How does employment fragmentation leave gig workers, contractors, and part-time workers unprotected?
What are portable benefits, and how would they decouple protections from specific employers?
What implementation challenges do portable benefits face in contributions, administration, and integration?
What is universal basic income, and what are the arguments for and against it?
What new social contract must recognize that dignity does not depend on a particular employment relationship?

chapters.name: Organizing the Unorganizable
topics: What fundamental challenges does the gig economy's fragmentation pose for traditional union organizing?
What real results has informal organizing achieved through driver strikes and social media coordination?
How do worker centers provide organizing infrastructure for workers excluded from traditional labor law?
What new model did the Freelancers Union pioneer for providing benefits and advocacy without collective bargaining?
What legal innovations—sectoral bargaining, portable benefit governance, new legal categories—could expand possibilities?
Why is building power through organizing, politics, and solidarity essential despite the form organizing takes?

chapters.name: What Do Workers Want?
topics: What does survey data reveal about the complexity of worker preferences for flexibility, stability, and dignity?
Why does flexibility genuinely matter to parents, workers with disabilities, and people with multiple commitments?
Why is flexibility without stability precarious, leaving workers anxious about variable pay and unpredictable hours?
What does dignity mean to workers—being treated as adults, recognition, voice in decisions?
Why do benefits matter enormously as the gap between traditional employment and gig work?
What would a genuinely worker-centered future look like—and is the obstacle feasibility or power?
